title: Sati (practice)
summary: Sati or suttee[note 1] is a historical Hindu practice in which a widow sacrificed herself by sitting atop her deceased husband's funeral pyre.[2][3][4][5] Greek sources from around 300 BCE make isolated mention of sati,[6][7][8] but it probably developed into a real fire sacrifice within the northwestern Rajput Kshatriya (warrior) varna, to which it remained limited, and became regular only after 500 CE,[9] to become wider-spread during the Muslim-era.[10][11][12]
